"petar_chervenski" 
<petar_chervenski@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Ken, 
> 
> The fit=
ness function used in the binary is Average_Head_Height * 
> Number_of_Foot=
Steps_Taken. The second multiplier rewards 
individuals 
> that tend to wal=
k around instead of staying still. I know it is 
maybe 
> wrong to assign 0=
.000 fitness, but I usually hope that in early 
> generations at least some=
 individuals will get a score above zero, 
> and therefore survive. Is this=
 a right thing to do or I should 
> translate all fitnesses above 0.000 ? L=
ike Total_Fitness +=3D 1.0; ? 
> The Number_of_FootSteps_Taken is actually =
an integer and it makes 
the 
> fitness landscape look like stairs... This =
is not good, but I can't 
> think of another way to encourage walking aroun=
d.. Rewarding cyclic 
> activity in the output neurons didn't help me much.=
. It is the same 
> thing. 
> 
> I am experimenting with a lot of fitness f=
unctions every day. The 
> best individual I got for the balancing task was=
 actually the same 
as 
> the one found using regular NEAT - just standing.=
 A way to prevent 
> this is may be to choose random initial positions for =
the model.. 
Or 
> the ground plane can be made moving randomly.. 
> Anyway=
, it seems that the fitness function is wrong, since this way 
> of achievi=
ng the goal is too easy for the evolution to find.
> 
> I am currently tryi=
ng out how good are they to walk. I replaced the 
> Average_Head_Height wit=
h Total_Distance_Travelled in the fitness 
> function. 
> 
> I believe that=
 HyperNEAT is able to handle such complex dynamic 
> control tasks, given t=
he right substrate geometry. Results so far 
do 
> not show a big progress.=
 But there are a lot of parameters to tweak 
> and play with. Substrate con=
figurations also. 
> 
> Ken, what about the source code, can you compile it=
?  
> 
> Peter
>
